addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

23 Ja
n
1591
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
Pasport grawnted to
M. de Bilandt
Musteringe of
e
Q.
troupes.
Death of
D. Casimir
& others./

page.lettertext:
fol.57r
May it please yo
r
good L. As I writte in
my last
e 10 of this moneth, there was
a Pasport graunted by this
Councel of Estate
(for suche respectes as I declared in that
letter) to Mons
r
de Bilandt Baron of Reide
and one of
e
Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs
for the
mater of Peace, to come hither to
e Hage:
who is therupon arrived, and hath required
audience of
e Councel. But having bin
heere but two daies, they have differred him
a while. Heerof, albeit as yet I have no
further mater, I thought it not unfitte, upon
occasion presented of a present messenger,
to advertise yo
r
L. as I also purpose to
informe yow, w
t
e first opportunitie, of
whatsoever shall passe in his accesse unto
e
Councel, or shall be pertinent otherwise to
e cause for whiche he comes.
Those troupes
at are appointed, to be sent out
of
Holland
to
e siege of
Rouen,
have bin em-
barked these 10 daies, and continue as yet
on shippe borde, that for want of a winde,
and by reason of
e season, w
ch
hath bin heere
very harde and stormy, it is said they doe
sicken, and waxe very weake.
The Councel of Estate hath already sent
Muster of
e Q. forces
their Commissaries, to passe a general Muster
of all her Ma
ties
forces: w
ch
was to be per-
fourmed, as neere as they could, before the
20 of this moneth. Assoone as they returne
fol.57v
I will take out copies of their rolles and
certificats, and send them presently to
M
r
Wilkes
. There is at this
instant intelligence from
Collen,
that D.
Casimir,
e
D. of Wirtenbergh
, and
e
Chan-
celo
r
of Poland
are all deceased of poison:
and
at
Richardus
great Uncle to
e yong
Count Palatin
nephewe to Casimir, doth
take
e government upon him for 6 monethes,
during
e nonage of
e yonge Prince.
This is hardly heere beleved, but yet ad-
vertised to divers.
And thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Ja
n
23 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
